[[James Stroud]] | website = }} '''Chris Ward''' (born June 27, 1960 in [[The Bronx]]) is an American [[country music]] singer. A former [[police officer]] and bull rider, Ward signed to [[Giant Records (Warner)|Giant Records]] in 1994. After recording [[demo (music)|demos]], he wrote [[Confederate Railroad]]'s 1995 single "See Ya".{{cite book|last1=Mansfield|first1=Brian|last2=Graff|first2=Gary|title=MusicHound country: the essential album guide|year=1997|publisher=Visible Ink|url=https://archive.org/details/musichoundcountr0000mans|url-access=registration|quote=chris ward see ya.}} Ward released his debut single "Fall Reaching" in 1996. Written by [[Robert Ellis Orrall]] and [[Josh Leo]], and originally recorded by Orrall in the duo [[Orrall & Wright]], the song received a favorable review from ''Billboard'', whose Deborah Evans Price said that it "should go a long way toward helping Ward get through the clutter of competition at country radio."{{cite magazine|last=Price|first=Deborah Evans|date=10 August 1996|title=Reviews|magazine=Billboard|page=41|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wgcEAAAAMBAJ&dq=%22chris+ward%22+%22Fall+reaching%22&pg=PA47-IA6}} The song spent two weeks on the [[Hot Country Songs]] charts, peaking at number 68.{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2008|publisher=Record Research, Inc|year=2008|page=446|isbn=978-0-89820-177-2}} Stroud and [[Dann Huff]] co-produced Ward's debut album ''One Step Beyond''.{{cite magazine|last=Flippo|first=Chet|date=29 June 1996|title=Giant's Chris Ward traded his police badge for singing career|magazine=Billboard|pages=28, 30|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pgkEAAAAMBAJ&dq=%22chris+ward%22+%22Fall+reaching%22&pg=PA28}} This album included the song "[[Only God (Could Stop Me Loving You)]]", co-written by [[Robert John "Mutt" Lange]]. Eric Zehnbauer of ''[[Country Standard Time]]'' gave the album a mostly-negative review, saying that it "shows too much of the cookie-cutter sameness that has plagued the recent 'hat act' stampede." Zehnbauer's review praised "Fall Reaching" and the up-tempo songs.{{cite web|url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/cdreview.asp?xid=547|title=''One Step Beyond'' review|last=Zehnbauer|first=Eric|work=Country Standard Time|accessdate=9 March 2012}} "When You Get to Be You" was covered by [[Lisa Brokop]] on her 1998 album [[When You Get to Be You|of the same name]]. ==Discography== ===''One Step Beyond'' (1996)=== {{Infobox album | italic_title = no | name = One Step Beyond | type = studio | artist = Chris Ward | cover = | alt = | released = {{Start date|1996|08|07}} | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = Country | length = {{Duration|m=34|s=25}} | label = Giant | producer = Dann Huff and James Stroud | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} {{Track listing | total_length = | title1 = One Step Beyond | writer1 = [[Max T.
